history.content: I believe some labs are more supportive than others, but in general the grad students would want you to be productive, and if that means that they have to answer your questions to help you get up to speed, then it's in their best interests to do so :) Expectations for beginning undergrad researchers vary depending on who you're working with (some professors don't expect much, some expect work leading up to a paper in the near future). I think that one of the worst things you can do as an undergrad researcher is to get stuck and not ask people questions - I've been at this stage before, and you would find that nothing really ends up getting done, you and your grad student are unsatisfied with the quality of work you do, etc. But conversely, the best undergrad researchers have enthusiasm and are eager to learn more - I think it's actually not so much about what you know now, as opposed to how much and how fast you're willing to learn. Mostly everyone will need to learn some new information/tools for their research, so don't feel bad about not knowing things right off the bat (for your specific case, if you're in applied ML, you can probably pick things up reasonably quickly, and 16a/b should be adequate preparation if you don't need too much extra math for your work). So the main thing is that if your grad student wants you to do good work, and if asking a ton of questions will help you get engaged with the research and do your best work, then go ahead - overcome the psychological blocks and ask! If they kick you out because of this (highly unlikely) then find yourself a group that actually wants to help you grow as a researcher :)

children.subject:
Just to add on, please ask your grad student all the questions you get! I am an undergrad researcher as well, and one skill I've found especially valuable is shamelessly asking questions. (Note: I usually first try to think about the answer, but if I can't get it then I'll ask). Your/our role as undergrad researchers is to learn and contribute, and this clearly means we will encounter many things we don't know. Asking questions is the best/most efficient way to deepen our understanding of material, and all grad students will be willing to answer them (that's part of their job of having undergrads :P). 
One last note, I found it helpful when I just started to have a 15-30 minute weekly session reserved specifically for my questions - as opposed to asking all of them in meetings (as sometimes the goals in meetings is more high level than some types of questions).

The RL professors are usually fairly open to undergrads joining, just that the bar of entry now is that you must get a lot of A+'s to even be considered. For other areas of ML, try talking to the grad students about doing research rather than the professor themselves. The easy way to get opportunities are to ask and figure out what the requirements are.
I would like to sincerely ask: how (where) does OP (or other people) find cool labs or research opportunity to participate in? How high are the bars are for entering these labs? Thanks!

history.content:
I've been lucky enough to work in a cool lab, but I feel grossly underqualified. I've only taken 61a/b and now I'm trying to ML work with downloading models and things of that sort.

I feel like I have a billion and one questions but I fear that asking too many would make my grad student reconsider letting me help in his lab. Are the expectations for beginning undergrad research assistants generally low? Said differently, if someone gives me a task way ahead of what I know now, is research culture generally supportive enough to get someone up to snuff even if they feel like they're way incompetent?
history.subject: EECS undergrad research: is it normal to have no idea what in the world's going on?
